abstract.t: This is an example of using markdown in the creation of an Internet Draft. The specific flavor of markdown being used is kramdown-rfc.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: More infomation can be found in . (An exmple of an informative reference to a draft in the middle of text. Note that referencing an Internet draft involves replacing “draft-“ in the name with “I-D.”)

section.title: Conventions and Definitions
section.t: The key words “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “NOT RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL” in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Use Cases
section.t: This section will include some use cases for our new protocol. The use cases conform to the guidelines found in . (Demonstrating a normative reference inline.)

Note that the section heading also includes an anchor name that can be referenced in a cross reference later in the document, as is done in of this document. (Demonstrating using a reference to a heading without writing an actual anchor, but rather using the heading name in lowercase and with dashes.)

section.title: First use case
section.t: Some text about the first use case. (and an example of using a second level heading.)

HTTP version 2 is defined in . (Demonstrating renaming a reference so that it is “HTTP2” instead of “RFC7540”. You need to do this the first time you use a reference. From here on in the document you can just use “HTTP2” in a reference.)

list.t: third item, with a reference to .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As outlined earlier in , there could be security issues in various use cases.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: This document has no IANA actions.

front.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.t: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

front.title: Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC 2119 Key Words

abstract.t: RFC 2119 specifies common key words that may be used in protocol specifications. This document aims to reduce the ambiguity by clarifying that only UPPERCASE usage of the key words have the defined special meanings.
Pervasive monitoring is a technical attack that should be mitigated in the design of IETF protocols, where possible.

front.title: The Internet is for End Users

abstract.t: This document explains why, when a conflict cannot be avoided, the IETF considers end users as its highest priority concern.

This specification describes an optimized expression of the semantics of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP), referred to as HTTP version 2 (HTTP/2). HTTP/2 enables a more efficient use of network resources and a reduced perception of latency by introducing header field compression and allowing multiple concurrent exchanges on the same connection. It also introduces unsolicited push of representations from servers to clients.
This specification is an alternative to, but does not obsolete, the HTTP/1.1 message syntax. HTTP's existing semantics remain unchanged.

section.title: Acknowledgments
section.t: Thanks to everyone who helped create the tools that let us use Markdown to create Internet Drafts.
